Row.Text: Jet Fighter unit that specialises in establishing air superiority. Requires [ICON_RES_ALUMINUM] Aluminum.
Use 5th Gen Fighters to neutralize enemy air power.

The 5th Generation Fighter deals heavy damage up to 18 tiles away. It has specialized promotions that significantly reduces damage. It is available on the discovery of Stealth, and does not become obsolete. Requires [ICON_RES_ALUMINUM] Aluminum.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The 5th Gen Fighter is based on the Lockheed Martin F-35 Lightning II, which is a family of single-seat, single-engine, all-weather stealth multirole fighters. The fifth-generation combat aircraft is designed to perform ground attack and air superiority missions. It has three main models: the F-35A conventional takeoff and landing (CTOL) variant, the F-35B short take-off and vertical-landing (STOVL) variant, and the F-35C carrier-based Catapult Assisted Take-Off But Arrested Recovery (CATOBAR) variant. On 31 July 2015, the United States Marines declared ready for deployment the first squadron of F-35B fighters after intensive testing. On 2 August 2016, the U.S. Air Force declared its first squadron of F-35A fighters combat-ready.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The F-35 descends from the X-35, the winning design of the Joint Strike Fighter (JSF) program. An aerospace industry team led by Lockheed Martin designed and manufactures it. Other major F-35 industry partners include Northrop Grumman, Pratt and Whitney and BAE Systems. The F-35 first flew on 15 December 2006. The United States plans to buy 2,663 aircraft. Its variants are to provide the bulk of the crewed tactical airpower of the U.S. Air Force, Navy and the Marine Corps over the coming decades. Deliveries of the F-35 for the U.S. military are scheduled until 2037 with a projected service life up to 2070.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The United States principally funds the F-35 JSF development, with additional funding from partners. The partner nations are either NATO members or close U.S. allies. The United Kingdom, Italy, Australia, Canada, Norway, Denmark, the Netherlands, and Turkey are part of the active development program; several additional countries have ordered, or are considering ordering, the F-35.
